docs.lead_paragraph: In another sign of renewed prosperity, the median income of New Jersey households during the past two years averaged $46,345, second only to Alaska among the 50 states and the District of Columbia, according to figures released yesterday by the United States Census Bureau.

headline.main: New Jersey Daily Briefing; Statistics Indicate Prosperity

docs.abstract: Median income of New Jersey households during past two years averaged $46,345, second only to Alaska (New Jersey Daily Briefing) (S)

docs.lead_paragraph: Pat LaFontaine officially joined the Rangers last night and could play when they open the regular season against the Islanders on Friday night at Madison Square Garden. ''I plan to,'' said LaFontaine, who will wear extra padding in his helmet to guard against additional concussions.

headline.main: Rangers Finally Make Deal for LaFontaine

docs.abstract: New York Rangers acquire Pat LaFontaine from Buffalo Sabres for second round draft choice in 1998 and future considerations (M)
docs.snippet: Pat LaFontaine officially joined the Rangers last night and could play when they open the regular season against the Islanders on Friday night at Madison Square Garden.    ''I plan to,'' said LaFontaine, who will wear extra padding in his helmet to...

docs.lead_paragraph: Four women opened a primary health care practice near Bloomingdale's in midtown Manhattan yesterday. But this group was different: The women are nurses, doing what doctors with a general or family practice ordinarily do. They treat common complaints like sore throats and abdominal pain and help patients deal with chronic conditions like asthma and diabetes. They diagnose the causes of all kinds of complaints and refer patients with complicated problems to specialists or admit them to the hospital. And they are accredited as primary-care providers by several big health maintenance organizations, which say they will pay them the same managed-care rates, typically $50 or $60 a visit, as they pay primary-care physicians.

headline.main: As Nurses Take On Primary Care, Physicians Are Sounding Alarms

docs.abstract: Highly trained nurses are assuming charge of patients without immediate supervision of doctors, practice endorsed by more and more private insurers as well as Medicare and Medicaid, but vehemently opposed by medical establishment and many doctors; nursing experts say nurse-practitioners can work in primary care as effectively as physicians and can add benefits of extra time and attention to whole person; private insurers and health care industry view innovation as additional tool to help cut costs; medical establishment says public has right to ask for real doctor, and must be protected from representation that nurse clinician is equivalent in training to physician; maps; photo (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Ruling Helps Hilton In Its Bid for ITT A judge ruled that ITT directors cannot split the company into three businesses without shareholder approval, a decision that buoyed Hilton's hostile $11.5 billion bid for ITT. The judge gave the company until Nov. 14 to hold a shareholders meeting. The three-way split was part of a strategy announced by Rand V. Araskog, the chief executive of ITT, to defeat the unsolicited bid that Hilton announced in January. [Page D8.]

docs.lead_paragraph: When Gov. Christine Todd Whitman announced her bid for re-election in the spring, she chose this small, middle-class town with a Republican mayor whose voters supported her over Jim Florio four years ago. But her support among the residents and merchants along Chestnut Street may not be as solid as Mrs. Whitman would hope, with the Nov. 4 election about five weeks away.

headline.main: The Talk in the Town Where Whitman Announced: Less Than Solid Support

docs.abstract: Gov Christine Todd Whitman, who announced her bid for re-election in spring in small, middle-class town of Roselle Park, has lost some support among town's residents and merchants; in dozens of interviews, as many people said they were voting for her Democratic opponent Sen James E McGreevey, as said they would vote for her re-election; major concern is seen as concern over property taxes and cost of auto insurance (M)
